@brian95123 Increase >25 bps seems unlikely here given market's expectation of 2 hikes in 2018 vs. Fed projection of 3 hikes. Fed has not hiked by 50 bps in a single meeting since May 2000. If more hawkish policy is necessary would more likely see an increased frequency of 25 bps hikes.

@veritasnaut @naval There is some evidence of skill, but after fees/costs the end result is worse than passive on avg. For investors like Naval whose performance has far exceeded those costs, the questions are: 1) how much luck vs. skill, 2) is skill repeatable, 3) how do u objectively measure this.

@veritasnaut @naval The evidence suggests otherwise. Doing it as a side gig (inactive passive investor in a diversified portfolio) outperforms professional active investors more often than not. More often than not is not always, leaving many exceptions for one to argue that there is skill involved.

@naval In most professions, you can get better by reading, learning, apprenticeship, practice, etc. In investing doing that may or may not be helpful (depending on what you are learning & luck), when doing nothing at all (owning a diversified portfolio) is likely to be the most helpful.

@potential2016 It is true that many factors influence overall interest rates in the long long run, but Fed policy at the short end of the curve is the most important factor by a wide margin. They are the principal driver of nominal interest rates, and by extension, real interest rates.

@potential2016 Not in my view. He's saying Fed policy did not effect real interest rates. How is that possible? They held nominal rates at 0% for 7 years. By definition that's keeping real interest rates at negative levels, lower than they would be if the Fed raised rates earlier in the cycle.
@trader_steve99 Generally up to 1 year, but 2-year bond also referred at as short-end in looking at yield curve spread.

@noCigar Agreed, AMT elimination is a win and long overdue, just so much more more in terms of simplifying that could be done if reform is the goal. Probably won't have another opportunity in a long time...

@noCigar Not suggesting they should pass nothing (unless nothing is better than the something they pass), saying I expected much more as they had 8 years to plan for this - why are they rushing to pass a flawed bill before year-end?

@noCigar no question, many differences here, mainly interesting to note the similarities in the "pass something" mentality with little care as to whether that "something" is actually best for this country long-term

What's the solution? There is none, this is politics 101. Government should operate under the mantra of "first, do no harm," not "get something, anything done" just for the sake of saying you got something done. Don't just do something, sit there and get it right or do nothing.

Which is why we shouldn't be surprised to see a similar outcome this time if a flawed/100% partisan bill is rushed through, with Democrats ultimately taking back senate/house, and nothing passed for remainder of Trump presidency, same as Obama after the ACA.

Today, we have an election coming up with Roy Moore that could very well shift the balance of power enough to make passage of tax bill difficult, similar to Scott Brown. No doubt they are trying to rush this through with that in mind...

Barack "if you like your doctor/plan, you can keep your doctor/plan" Obama signs it, law never becomes popular, republicans take back house and have no incentive to fix something they didn't vote for.
Democrats lose their filibuster-proof majority, and house has to pass the highly flawed senate bill that nobody read and nobody thought would be the final bill...

Few read the actual bill, was supposed to go to the house, then back to the senate, with many opportunities for changes. Then something unexpected happens in Jan 2010. Scott Brown, who ran on a platform against ACA, wins Ted Kennedy's seat in Mass..

In late 2009, polling for ACA was getting worse and worse, and Harry Reid rushes a 2,700 page bill for senate to vote on with only 6 days of debate. Was a "Christmas deadline." Bill passes 60-39 strictly on party lines...

ACA bill was so harmful/hated that republicans took back the house, then the senate, then the presidency. Now republicans turn to pass rushed, flawed bills and democrats will take back house/senate, then presidency in 2020.
Ironic because democrats did the same exact thing with the Affordable Care Act, rushing it through to pass w/o one republican on board...
A highly flawed bill that is being rushed through to say "we're doing something." This is not real tax reform by any stretch of the imagination.

So the question today is as follows: are conditions over the next year likely to be as definitely awesome as they are today? If the answer is no, how will the increased uncertainty be treated by the market, with more or less volatility?

Buy each dip as if it were your last.
... they know that corrections haven't been eradicated but they won't believe their dip buy can fail until they see it with their own eyes.
... we haven't seen that in over a year. Market participants are now conditioned to believe any and all dip buys will soon hit new highs...
... it may sound obvious, but only a dip that fails to reach a new high and instead breaks below a prior low can stop the positive loop...
... the longer the uptrend, the harder it is to break, as the feedback loop strengthens with each and every successful dip buy...
... where observers note that the buying of any minor dip has been soon rewarded with new highs, which emboldens them to do the same...
Psychology driving long uptrends is the positive feed back loop...

Which office environment are you currently working in?
Which office environment would be most productive for what you do?
@HarryWanger tell me about it
Spending 9 distracted hours in an office every day when you could be working 6 hours or less w/ focus is beyond frustrating for avg worker.
Likely a conservative estimate based on my experience & how our brains work. Some may like being unproductive but my guess is most don't...
I would venture to guess that open office space workers are at least a third less productive as they could be if they had a quiet work space
We're increasingly moving to a knowledge-worker economy where focus/deep thought is paramount. And yet myth of open office space persists.
Being interrupted all day long is not collaboration, it's distraction. Since we can't multitask distractions = loss of focus/productivity.
Amount of productivity & creative thought that is lost through the open office space is astronomical. Notion of "collaboration" is a myth...
The open office space is a farce. Anyone who needs to focus - writers, creators, planners - thrive in quiet, distraction-free environments.

Macroeconomics and markets are not hard sciences and we should not treat them as such. Mostly conjecture and folk tales in this field.
Did easy money play a role in the Tech/Housing Bubbles? Probably, but we cannot say with certainty b/c we cannot test the counterfactuals.
Whether that's a good thing or a bad thing can never be proven. It is not falsifiable as you cannot simultaneously test the counterfactuals.

That doesn't mean we can't top here and now, just that extremely low volatility has been a poor predictor of such things in the past...

That doesn't mean the market can't go down over the next year, just that you can't say that's a likely outcome based on extreme greed alone.
Many assume that extreme greed means a crash is imminent. The historical data says otherwise - just increased odds of  a below avg return.
There is no holy grail in markets, just probabilities. The odds say that extreme fear is good & extreme greed is less good, on average...
